concepts.unlisted_label: Principle of Indivisibility of Mortgage Decree

issues.text: Whether full satisfaction of the mortgage decree can be recorded under section 47 and Order 21 rule 2 CPC upon the deposit by defendant No. 1 together with payments by defendants 2 to 7 equalling the scaled down amount decreed against defendants 2 to 7, thereby exonerating all mortgaged properties and defendant No. 1 from further liability invoking indivisibility of the mortgage debt?

anchor.surface_text: deposited in court a sum of Rs. 3,215 and put in a petition under section 47 and Order 21, rule 2, Civil Procedure Code, praying that as the amount thus deposited together with the payments already made completely wiped off the amount due under the decree as scaled down by the High Court in favour of defendants 2 to 7, full satisfaction of the decree might be recorded exonerating the mortgaged properties and also the defendant No. 1 himself from any further liability in respect of the decretal debt. The position taken up by defendant No. 1, in substance, was that the mortgage debt was one and indivisible

issues.text: Whether the High Court sitting as an executing court could interpret the decree to allow full satisfaction and exoneration beyond its express terms directing separate payments by defendant No. 1 and defendants 2 to 7?

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the High Courts approach to the case has not been a proper one and the conclusion it has reached cannot be supported in law. The learned Judges appear to have overlooked the fact that they were sitting only as an executing court and their duty was to give effect to the terms of the decree that was already passed and beyond which they could not go.

issues.text: Whether the principle of indivisibility of a mortgage decree entitles a non-agriculturist judgment-debtor (defendant No. 1) to indirectly benefit from the scaling down of the decree under the Madras Agriculturists Relief Act granted only to agriculturist co-debtors (defendants 2 to 7)?

anchor.surface_text: by operation of the principle of indivisibility of the mortgage decree, a non-agriculturist debtor, whose debt has not been scaled down under the provisions of the Agriculturists Relief Act, may indirectly get the benefit of the relief which has been granted to his agriculturist co-debtor under the provisions of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the Madras Agriculturists Relief Act permits the scaling down of a mortgage decree in favour of agriculturist judgment-debtors only, leaving the decree intact against non-agriculturist co-debtors and thereby splitting the decree?

anchor.surface_text: section 7 of the Act expressly provides that notwithstanding any law, custom, contract or decree of court to the contrary, all debts payable by an agriculturist at the commencement of this Act shall be scaled down in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. Thus in case of a mortgage debt when the loan has been advanced to more than one person, if one of the debtors happens to be an agriculturist while others are not, the agriculturist debtor would certainly be entitled to have his debts scaled down under the provisions of the Act

arguments.claim: Full satisfaction of the decree should be recorded under s.47 and O. XXI r.2 CPC as the deposit by defendant No.1 together with payments by defendants 2-7 equals the scaled-down amount, exonerating all properties and defendant No.1 due to indivisibility of the mortgage debt.

The position taken up by defendant No. 1, in substance, was that the mortgage debt was one and indivisible and even though different amounts were mentioned as payable by two groups of defendants in the decree,

arguments.claim: Executing court (High Court) must apply principle of unity and indivisibility of mortgage decree, allowing non-agriculturist to indirectly benefit from scaling down granted to co-debtors.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court overlooked its role as executing court limited to enforcing decree terms without remaking it.

arguments.claim: High Court's approach improper as executing court; duty is to enforce decree terms without going beyond or remaking under guise of interpretation.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the High Courts approach to the case has not been a proper one and the conclusion it has reached cannot be supported in law. The learned Judges appear to have overlooked the fact that they were sitting only as an executing court and their duty was to give effect to the terms of the decree that was already passed and beyond which they could not go.

arguments.claim: Decree directs separate payments: scaled amount for defendants 2-7, full amount for defendant No.1; payment of scaled amount does not automatically exonerate all properties or defendant No.1.

anchor.surface_text: As said above, the mortgage decree was scaled down by the High Court in favour of defendants 2 to 7 only and the amended decree directs that the said defendants do pay into court the sum of Rs. 49,255 with certain interest and costs on payment of which the plaintiff was to bring into court all the documents...

arguments.claim: General principle of mortgage decree indivisibility does not apply; MARA s.7 overrides to scale down debts of agriculturists only, permitting split decree against non-agriculturists.

anchor.surface_text: The general law undoubtedly is that a mortgage decree is one and indivisible and exceptions to this rule are admitted in special circumstances... section 7 of the Act expressly provides that notwithstanding any law, custom, contract or decree of court to the contrary, all debts payable by an agriculturist...

arguments.claim: Precedent Rainier v. Srinivasiah supports scaling down mortgage decree for some debtors only, splitting it.

anchor.surface_text: The Madras High Court expressly adopted this view in Rainier v. Srinivasiah, which is one of the decisions referred to in the judgment appealed from. The fact that in that case it was a puisne mortgagee and not a mortgagor whose application for relief under section 19...

arguments.claim: MARA s.14 indicates scheme allows splitting debts in joint families based on agriculturist status.

anchor.surface_text: section 14 of the Madras Agriculturists Relief Act which provides for separation of a debt incurred by a Hindu family, some members of which are agriculturists while others are not, affords a clear indication that the splitting up of a debt in such circumstances is quite in accordance with the scheme of the Act.

arguments.claim: Cases like Arunachalam Pillai, Pachigola v. Karatam, Subramanian v. Ramachandra on purchasers benefiting from scaling down not applicable here, as no purchaser involved; debtors are original mortgagors.

anchor.surface_text: The catena of cases upon which the learned Judges of the High Court relied... In the present case there is no purchaser of the mortgaged property and consequently there is no question of the purchaser, who is not an agriculturist himself, being entitled to the benefit...

arguments.claim: Defendant No.1 not entitled to scaling down as no application made and later claims rejected.

anchor.surface_text: District Judge made in a proceeding under section 47 and Order 21, rule 2, of the Civil Procedure Code... The application was dismissed on February 25, 1943, on the ground that as the decree had already been passed by the High Court definitely negativing his claim to any relief under the Agriculturists Relief Act...

arguments.claim: Decree should be interpreted to direct sale of defendants 2-7's interest only on their default, but whole property for defendant No.1's liability.

anchor.surface_text: Some exception could undoubtedly be taken to the form and wording of the decree... The further direction should have been that in case they did not pay this amount, the whole of the mortgaged property including their interest would be sold for the entirety of the mortgage debt...

holdings.text: The High Court's approach was improper as it was sitting only as an executing court and its duty was to give effect to the terms of the decree without going beyond it.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the High Courts approach to the case has not been a proper one and the conclusion it has reached cannot be supported in law. The learned Judges appear to have overlooked the fact that they were sitting only as an executing court and their duty was to give effect to the terms of the decree that was already passed and beyond which they could not go.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Executing court interprets and enforces existing decree terms without remaking or altering it under guise of interpretation.

holdings.text: The decree directs separate payments: scaled down amount for defendants 2 to 7 and full amount for defendant No. 1; payment of the scaled amount does not exonerate the entire mortgaged property or defendant No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: As said above, the mortgage decree was scaled down by the High Court in favour of defendants 2 to 7 only and the amended decree directs that the said defendants do pay into court the sum of Rs. 49,255 with certain interest and costs on payment of which the plaintiff was to bring into court all the documents...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of decree terms specifying distinct liabilities and consequences for each group of defendants.

holdings.text: A non-agriculturist debtor cannot indirectly benefit from scaling down granted to agriculturist co-debtors by operation of the principle of indivisibility of mortgage decree.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed in substance with this contention and based its decision entirely upon the view that by operation of the principle of indivisibility of the mortgage decree, a non-agriculturist debtor, whose debt has not been scaled down under the provisions of the Agriculturists Relief Act, may indirectly get the benefit of the relief which has been granted to his agriculturist co-debtor under the provisions of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General indivisibility principle overridden by special MARA provisions applying only to agriculturists.

holdings.text: The Madras Agriculturists Relief Act permits scaling down of mortgage decree in favour of agriculturist judgment-debtors only, leaving it intact against non-agriculturist co-debtors, thereby splitting the decree notwithstanding general law on indivisibility.

anchor.surface_text: section 7 of the Act expressly provides that notwithstanding any law, custom, contract or decree of court to the contrary, all debts payable by an agriculturist at the commencement of this Act shall be scaled down in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. Thus in case of a mortgage debt when the loan has been advanced to more than one person, if one of the debtors happens to be an agriculturist while others are not, the agriculturist debtor would certainly be entitled to have his debts scaled down under the provisions of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 7 MARA expressly overrides general law; supported by s.14 and precedent like Rainier v. Srinivasiah.

holdings.text: Full satisfaction of the decree cannot be recorded under section 47 CPC and Order XXI rule 2 upon deposit by defendant No. 1 together with scaled payments by defendants 2 to 7, as it would violate express decree terms and permit unauthorized splitting benefit.

anchor.surface_text: deposited in court a sum of Rs. 3,215 and put in a petition under section 47 and Order 21, rule 2, Civil Procedure Code, praying that as the amount thus deposited together with the payments already made completely wiped off the amount due under the decree as scaled down by the High Court in favour of defendants 2 to 7, full satisfaction of the decree might be recorded exonerating the mortgaged properties and also the defendant No. 1 himself from any further liability in respect of the decretal debt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines executing court limits, decree interpretation, and MARA non-applicability to non-agriculturist.

holdings.text: Precedents on purchasers of equity of redemption benefiting from scaling down (e.g., Arunachalam Pillai, Pachigola v. Karatam, Subramanian v. Ramachandra) are inapplicable where judgment-debtors are original mortgagors, not purchasers.

anchor.surface_text: The catena of cases upon which the learned Judges of the High Court relied... In the present case there is no purchaser of the mortgaged property and consequently there is no question of the purchaser, who is not an agriculturist himself, being entitled to the benefit...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction in facts: purchasers take subject to scaled burden; original non-agriculturist debtors do not get relief.

anchor.surface_text: The Madras High Court expressly adopted this view in Rainier v. Srinivasiah 1 , which is one of the 1 1940 2 M. 39 decisions referred to in the judgment appealed from. The fact that in that case it was a puisne mortgagee and not a mortgagor whose application for relief under section 19 of the Madras Agriculturists Relief Act was allowed, does not make any difference in principle.

precedents.cited_proposition: nothing wrong in law in scaling down a mortgage decree in favour of one of the judgment debtors while as regards others the decree is kept intact

anchor.surface_text: The reason for taking this view was thus given by the learned Judges in Arunachalam Pillai Seetharam 1 , where the purchase of the equity of redemp- tion was at an execution sale-- When the 12th respondent purchased the properties in companyrt auction, he took them subject to the burden of the appellants mortgage and if the burden is by reason of the provisions of s. 8

precedents.cited_proposition: non-agriculturist purchaser at court auction takes property subject to reduced mortgage burden as an advantageous purchase incident under general law
precedents.cited_holding: When the 12th respondent purchased the properties in companyrt auction, he took them subject to the burden of the appellants mortgage and if the burden is by reason of the provisions of s. 8 refer.red to above reduced without pay- ment, the purchase proves to that extent an advantageous one

anchor.surface_text: A somewhat different reason was assigned in Pachigola v. Karatam 1  which however was a case where a portion of the. equity of redemption was transferred to a purchaser by a private sale. It was held that the companyrt by allowing the mortgagor to redeem the mortgage sale was number companyferring on the purchaser, a number-agriculturist, the benefit of the Act, as he would have to refund to his vendor the purchase money reserved with him which as a result of the scaling down he would number have to pay to the mortgagee.

precedents.cited_proposition: non-agriculturist purchaser by private sale gets scaling down benefit indirectly through refunding less purchase money to vendor

anchor.surface_text: There is however the case of Subramanian v. Ramachandra  2 , where the question arose in companyrse of execution pro- ceedings and a purchaser of a portion of the equity of redemption was held to be entitled to the benefit of the scaled down decree in favour of the mortgagors, although his own application for relief under the Act was refused.

precedents.cited_proposition: purchaser of equity of redemption entitled to scaled down decree benefit even if own application for relief refused, in execution proceedings

anchor.surface_text: section 7 of the Act expressly provides that notwithstanding any law, custom, contract or decree of court to the contrary, all debts payable by an agriculturist at the commencement of this Act shall be scaled down in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. Thus in case of a mortgage debt when the loan has been advanced to more than one person, if one of the debtors happens to be an agriculturist while others are not, the agriculturist debtor would certainly be entitled to have his debts scaled down under the provisions of the Act
